pageData.text: Nutrients are essential for body maintenance, growth, and development and are often stored in food in such a way that they are not readily available to the cells of the body. The digestive system is responsible for the mechanical and chemical breakdown of food followed by absorption of the nutrients. Mechanically, food size is reduced by chewing (mastication) and segmentation in the . Digestive enzymes play an important role in the chemical breakdown of food. The components of the digestive system include the and the . Each organ has a unique function and histological makeup.

pageData.text: Gastroscopy has become an extremely important tool in the diagnosis of gastrointestinal (GI) diseases, such as those that cause pain, bleeding ulcers and stomach acid problems, and in the treatment of blockages, tumors, and non-cancerous growths. During a gastroscopy procedure, a thin flexible tube supporting a light and camera, known as an endoscope, is used to look inside the , stomach, and first part of the in real time.In 1858, Adolph Kussmaul invented the first endoscope for observing the upper GI tract. At the time, endoscopes were used to diagnose urinary system diseases and was designed for insertion into the urethras of male patients. Kussmaul thought it too challenging to use an endoscope to reach the upper GI tract in this way, so he decided on a different approach. By employing a professional sword swallower, who could relax his upper esophageal sphincter, Kussmaul was able to insert a 47-cm long, 13-mm diameter rigid tube containing mirrors and an external gas lamp light into the test subject and observe his upper GI tract. Despite the light source being insufficient, Kussmaul considered his invention a success. He never published his work regarding the endoscope, but he consulted a group that refined the procedure years later1.

1Rehnberg, V., & Walters, E. (2017). The life and work of Adolph Kussmaul 1822-1902: 'Sword swallowers in modern medicine'. Journal of the Intensive Care Society, 18(1), 71-72. https://doi.org/10.1177/1751143716676822

pageData.desc: A drawing of a sword swallower ingesting a sword alongside a picture-in-picture cross section of the sword swallower's neck and torso showing the placement of the sword, heart, stomach, lungs and liver.
pageData.altText: A drawing of a sword swallower ingesting a sword alongside a picture-in-picture cross section of the sword swallower's neck and torso showing the placement of the sword, heart, stomach, lungs and liver.

pageData.text: The main functions of the digestive system are mechanical and chemical digestion, and absorption. Digestion is the process in which the body breaks food down into smaller molecules so that nutrients can be easily absorbed. The entire digestion process can take anywhere from 24 to 50 hours.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Digestive System

pageData.subTitle: Mouth/Esophagus
pageData.text: Digestion begins in the mouth through the mechanical and chemical breakdown of food. Smooth muscle tissue in the esophagus squeezes the food down toward the stomach in a process called peristalsis.

pageData.subTitle: Stomach
pageData.text: Mechanical and chemical digestion continues in the stomach. Smooth muscle tissue in the stomach wall squeezes and churns the material, while enzymes and chemicals are added to help further break down the food.

pageData.subTitle: Stomach structure
pageData.text: The internal structure of the stomach has ridges and folds called rugae. This increases the surface area within the stomach and allows it to expand to hold more food.

pageData.subTitle: Intestines
pageData.text: The small intestine and large intestine (colon) combined average 25 feet long.

pageData.subTitle: Small Intestine
pageData.text: The majority of absorption takes place in the small intestine, which is about 20 feet long. The small intestine has 3 sections: duodenum, jejunum, and ileum.Finger-like extensions called villi and microvilli increase the surface area of the small intestine, allowing maximum absorption of nutrients and water.

pageData.altText: Small Intestine

pageData.subTitle: <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Large Intestine
pageData.text: The large intestine, about 5 feet long, is responsible for eliminating waste matter.

pageData.altText: Large Intestine

pageData.text: The digestive system is made up of the and the (see Figure 1). The alimentary canal starts with the oral cavity, where the food is mechanically broken down into smaller pieces and mixed with saliva. From there, it goes through the before entering a muscular tube, called the . Next, the food enters the , where acids continue to break it down chemically, ensuring that nutrients can be absorbed in the . Any remaining material then enters the , which combines waste from the body and waste from bacteria (inhabiting our intestines) before elimination from the body.

The accessory organs of the digestive system include the pancreas, , and gallbladder, which produce enzymes that aid in the chemical digestion process and assist in removing toxins from the body by preparing them for elimination.

pageData.text: The tissue of the <button class='glossary-text'>alimentary canal</button> is made up of 4 distinct layers, as seen in the section of the <button class='glossary-text'>small intestine</button> shown in Figure 2.

text: The inner most layer, the , consists of either simple or stratified epithelium. The top part of the alimentary canal contains mainly , while the lower part, from the down, mainly consists of columnar epithelium. In this layer of epithelial cells are , which secrete alkaline mucus. The epithelium sits on top of a layer of loose , the . This layer is characterized by longitudinal and transverse folds, the . This folding helps to increase the surface area, which allows for better absorption of the nutrients.
The next layer is the . This mainly comprises dense irregular tissue and connects the mucosa to the muscular layer, the . The submucosa layer contains blood and and nerves.

The muscularis is made up of smooth muscle that assists in moving the nutrients through the alimentary canal. To do this, the muscles are arranged in a circular inner layer covered in a layer of longitudinal muscles. Together, these muscles squeeze the nutrients along.
The outer most layer, the , is made up of and encapsulates the entire alimentary canal.

pageData.question: What is the function of the plicae in the alimentary canal?

options.text: produce enzymes that aid in chemical digestion

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The plicae are longitudinal and transverse folds in the lamina propria that increase the surface area of the tissue, which allows for better absorption of nutrients.

pageData.question: In what layer of the alimentary canal are the plicae found?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The epithelium sits on top of a layer of loose connective tissue, the lamina propria, which contains longitudinal and transverse folding, or plicae.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The tissue of the alimentary canal is made up of 4 distinct layers. The innermost layer, the mucosa, consists of either simple or stratified epithelium depending on the region of the body in which it is found. This layer also contains goblet glands, which secrete alkaline mucus. The layer superficial to the mucosa is a layer of loose connective tissue called the lamina propria. This layer is characterized by longitudinal and transverse folds, or plicae. The increased surface area of the plicae allows for better absorption of nutrients. The next layer out is the submucosa. This is mainly comprised of dense irregular tissue and connects the mucosa to the muscular layer, the muscularis, which is the deep to the submucosa. The submucosa layer contains blood and lymphatic vessels and nerves. The outermost layer is the serosa.

img.alt: Figure 3: A close-up of the mammal small intestine microscope slide with the layers labeled

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The tissue of the alimentary canal is made up of 4 distinct layers. The innermost layer, the mucosa, consists of either simple or stratified epithelium depending on the region of the body in which it is found. This layer also contains goblet glands, which secrete alkaline mucus. The layer superficial to the mucosa is a layer of loose connective tissue called the lamina propria. This layer is characterized by longitudinal and transverse folds, or plicae. The increased surface area of the plicae allows for better absorption of nutrients. The next layer out is the submucosa. This is mainly comprised of dense irregular tissue and connects the mucosa to the muscular layer, the muscularis, which is the deep to the submucosa. The submucosa layer contains blood and lymphatic vessels and nerves. The outermost layer is the serosa.

img.alt: Figure 3: A close-up of the mammal small intestine microscope slide with the layers labeled

pageData.subTitle: Nutrient Absorption
pageData.text: As can be seen in and 3, the of the has fingerlike projections, called , along the transverse or the circular folds of the small intestine. These villi are made up of columnar epithelium, which have even smaller on their surface. These microvilli and villi are in continuous motion, which increases the surface area and the efficiency of nutrient absorption. The has a network of capillaries that allows for quick uptake of nutrients and delivery to the . Some nutrients, such as lipids, cannot be readily absorbed into the blood stream and are taken up by the present in the submucosa, called the . The lymphatic vessel transports the lipids to the left , where they then enter the bloodstream.

The lacks villi and microvilli and has an abundance of goblet cells. The mucus produced by these cells acts as a lubricant of the fecal material. The longitudinal muscles are confined to small patches, called the , and their arrangement forms pocketlike sacs, called .

pageData.subTitle: Accessory Organs
pageData.text: One example of an is the . The liver is the largest internal organ and has four primary lobes: the large right lobe, the smaller left lobe, and the caudate and quadrate lobes. The structural and functional units of the liver are called (see Figures 4 and ). Each lobule is separated from the other lobules by an . These septa are made up of strands of . Each lobule contains the functional cells of the liver, the . These hepatocytes are arranged in one-cell-layer-thick plates, also known as . Around each of these plates are discontinuous capillaries, the . These transport the nutrients and waste products (see ) throughout the lobule to be processed by the hepatocyte. Blood exits the lobule through a larger located in the center of each lobule, which brings the blood to the . The cords are lined with specialized cells from the immune system called the . These cells will encapsulate any foreign substance.

pageData.question: What are the structural and functional units of the liver?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The structural and functional units of the liver are the liver lobules.

pageData.question: This is a micrograph of liver tissue. Which of these structures is the lobule?

imageData.desc: A liver micrograph. The connective tissue strands separating oblong regions of cells is labeled number one. The opening at the center of an oblong region of cells is labeled number two. A thin grouping of liver cells is labeled number three. An oblong region of cells surrounded by connective tissue is labeled number four. A tight circular structure at a junction in the connective tissue is labeled number five.
imageData.altText: A liver micrograph. The connective tissue strands separating oblong regions of cells is labeled number one. The opening at the center of an oblong region of cells is labeled number two. A thin grouping of liver cells is labeled number three. An oblong region of cells surrounded by connective tissue is labeled number four. A tight circular structure at a junction in the connective tissue is labeled number five.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The lobule is separated by other lobules by strands of connective tissue (the septa) and contains many hepatocytes.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: One example of an accessory organ is the liver. It is made up of liver lobules as its structural and functional units. Each lobule is separated from the other lobules by an interlobular septum. These septa are made up of strands of connective tissue. Each lobule contains the functional cells of the liver, the hepatocytes.

img.alt: Figure 4: The labeled structure of a liver lobule

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: One example of an accessory organ is the liver. It is made up of liver lobules as its structural and functional units. Each lobule is separated from the other lobules by an interlobular septum. These septa are made up of strands of connective tissue. Each lobule contains the functional cells of the liver, the hepatocytes.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, set up the microscope. In Activity 1, place the duodenum slide on the stage, focus the tissue layers in the field of view, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification, and identify its layers. Then, calculate the total magnification and compare the characteristics of each layer. Lastly, focus on the villi, identify structures in the field of view, and calculate the total magnification. In Activity 2, place the colon slide on the stage, focus on the tissue layers in the field of view, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification, and identify its layers. Then, calculate the total magnification and compare the characteristics of each layer. In Activity 3, place the liver slide on the stage, focus on a lobule in the field of view, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification, and identify its structures. Lastly, calculate the total magnification and compare the characteristics of each structure.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Introduction to Histology: Digestive System investigation (item number 580574) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Read all the instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Ensure that any broken or discarded microscope slides are disposed of properly. Put them in a hard-sided container (such as a small, sturdy cardboard box) before placing them in the household trash.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is an accessory organ of the human digestive system?
Which of the following best describes the function and location of goblet cells in the wall of the alimentary canal?
Structures of the alimentary canal wall, such as plicae and microvilli, facilitate absorption of nutrients through which of the following properties?
Which of the following best describes the large intestine relative to the small intestine?

options.text: It has fewer villi but more goblet cells.
It has more villi and more goblet cells.
It has fewer villi and fewer goblet cells.
It has just as many villi but more goblet cells.
It has just as many villi but fewer goblet cells.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the structural and functional unit of the liver and the functional cells of which it is made?

options.text: The liver lobule is made up of hepatocytes.
The liver lobule is made up of interlobular septa.
The cord is made up of hepatocytes.
The sinusoid is made up of Kupffer cells.
The sinusoid is made up of cords.

assestmentData.question: Blood exits the liver lobules through which of the following vessels?
Which of the following describes the mammalian microscope slides you will observe in this investigation?
Into which of the following items would it be appropriate to place discarded microscope slides before placing them in the household trash at the conclusion of this investigation?

options.text: a large piece of toilet paper
No intermediate container is necessary for slides disposal.

Select a work area that is near an electrical outlet if using a corded microscope.
Obtain all listed needed materials from your kit. (Remember: when carrying your microscope, grasp it by the arm and support the base.)
Familiarize yourself with your microscope. Identify its key parts. Consult the instructions that came with your microscope if you have any difficulty finding a specific part.
Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion (100x) objective, identify it, but do not use it during this investigation.

Be aware of your instructorâ€™s directions for documenting your work. You may be asked to draw pictures and either photograph or scan them for submission, or you may need to take pictures through the microscope using a digital camera or mobile device. To learn how to take photos through the microscope, see the following video:

pageData.desc: How to Take a Picture Through a Microscope

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will observe duodenum tissue under the microscope, including the villi and <button class='glossary-text'>microvilli</button>.
Collect the duodenum slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Note: Remember, the label should be faceup on the left.
Center and focus the slide in the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that clearly shows the different layers of the duodenum. Increase the magnification until you can clearly distinguish the different layers.

Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish. In a section of the duodenum, locate and indicate the â€”including the , , and â€”in the picture. Also, record the total magnification needed to best view the object in the â€œObservationsâ€ section.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Write the answers to the following questions in Data Table 1: What makes these layers stand out? What is specific for each layer when compared to the surrounding tissue? What are the main details you observe?
Focus on the villi, and increase the magnification.
Locate the upper part of the villi, and identify the <button class='glossary-text'>microvilli</button>.

Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and identify the villi and microvilli. Also, record the total magnification needed to best view the object in the â€œObservationsâ€ section in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Return to the lowest power.
Replace the slide in the slide box.
In Activity 2, you will observe colon tissue under the microscope.
Collect the colon slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide in the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that clearly shows the different layers of the colon. Increase the magnification until you can clearly distinguish the different layers.

Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish. In a section of the colon, locate and indicate the â€”including the , , and â€”in the picture. Also, record the total magnification needed to best view the object in the â€œObservationsâ€ section in Data Table 2.

pageData.text: Write the answers to the following questions in Data Table 2: What makes these layers stand out? What is specific for each layer when compared to the surrounding tissue? What are the main details you observe?
Replace the slide in the slide box.
In Activity 3, you will observe <button class='glossary-text'>liver</button> tissue under the microscope.
Collect the <button class='glossary-text'>liver</button> slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide in the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that shows a good view of a . Increase the magnification until you can clearly distinguish the different parts.

Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish. In a section of the liver, locate and indicate a , the capillaries, the hepatic and , and the in the picture. Also, record the total magnification needed to best view the object in the â€œObservationsâ€ section in Data Table 3.

pageData.text: Write the answers to the following questions in Data Table 3: What makes these layers stand out? What is specific for each layer when compared to the surrounding tissue? What are the main details you observe?
Replace the slide in the slide box.

Cover the microscope, and store it for future use.

data.title: Accessory organs
data.content: Organs that facilitate the function of other organs of the same body system

data.title: Alimentary canal
data.content: The pathway by which food enters, and solid wastes are expelled from, the body

data.title: Areolar connective tissue
data.content: Loose, irregularly arranged connective tissue that consists of collagenous and elastic fibers

data.title: Central vein
data.content: The vein located in the center of each liver lobule that brings blood to the hepatic veins

data.title: Connective tissues
data.content: The diverse group of tissues that link and support other tissues

data.title: Cords
data.content: Hepatocytes that are arranged in one-cell-layer-thick plates

data.title: Esophagus
data.content: A muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach

data.title: Goblet glands
data.content: Glands that produce the mucus necessary to moisten and lubricate the alimentary canal; also called goblet cells

data.title: Haustra
data.content: Segmented pouches of the colon that give the proximal colon a lumpy appearance

data.title: Hepatic veins
data.content: Blood vessels that return deoxygenated blood from the liver to the heart

data.title: Hepatocytes
data.content: The functional cells of the liver

data.title: Interlobular septum
data.content: Strands of connective tissue that separate liver lobules from each other

data.title: Intestinal villi
data.content: Fingerlike projections in the mucosa of the small intestine

data.title: Kupffer cells
data.content: Specialized cells from the immune system that line the cords of the liver

data.title: Lacteal
data.content: The lymphatic vessel in the submucosa of the small intestine that transports lipids to the subclavian vein

data.title: Lamina propria
data.content: A layer of loose connective tissue present throughout the alimentary canal

data.title: Large intestine
data.content: The tube-like organ that is connected to the small intestine at one end and the anus at the other; it combines waste from the body and intestine-inhabiting bacteria before eliminating it from the body

data.title: Liver
data.content: A large organ that sits on the right side of the belly and performs many important functions, including toxin removal, blood sugar maintenance, and blood clot regulation

data.title: Liver lobules
data.content: The structural and functional units of the liver

data.title: Lymphatic vessel
data.content: A vessel of the lymphatic system that carries lymph and white blood cells, and absorbs fats and fat-soluble vitamins from the digestive system

data.title: Microvilli
data.content: The microscopic projections on the surface of some cells that increases their surface area

data.title: Mucosa
data.content: The inner tissue layer of some organs and body cavities

data.title: Muscularis
data.content: The smooth muscular layer of the small intestine made up of smooth muscle cells arranged in a circular inner layer covered in a layer of longitudinal muscles that, together, squeeze nutrients along

data.title: Pharynx
data.content: The muscular passageway that connects the sinuses and nasal cavity to the trachea; commonly referred to as the throat

data.title: Plicae
data.content: Folds in the lamina propria of the small intestine that help to increase its surface area, which facilitates nutrient absorption

data.title: Serosa
data.content: The outer lining of organs and body cavities of the abdomen and chest, including the entire alimentary canal

data.title: Sinusoids
data.content: Discontinuous capillaries that surround each cord in the liver

data.title: Small intestine
data.content: The tube-like organ that is connected to the stomach at one end and the large intestine at the other; it finishes digesting food coming from the stomach and absorbs nutrients into the bloodstream

data.title: Squamous epithelium
data.content: A type of epithelial tissue composed of cells that have a flattened, tile-like shape

data.title: Stomach
data.content: A muscular organ located on the left side of the upper abdomen that receives and partially digests food from the esophagus

data.title: Subclavian vein
data.content: The vein that receives lipids from the lacteal in the small intestine and delivers them to the bloodsteam

data.title: Submucosa
data.content: The layer of irregular tissue that connects the mucosa and muscularis layers in the small intestine

data.title: Taenia coli
data.content: The external longitudinal muscle bands of the large intestine, the arrangement of which forms haustra
